CRIME NO.14/2004 OF KODUNGALLUR Excise Range Office , Thrissur PETITIONER/ACCUSED: PRADEEP KUMAR AGED 58 YEARS s/o KONNI , KOLANTHARA HOUSE, CHENTHRAPPINNI DESOM,EDATHIRUTHY VILLAGE ,KODUNGALLUR TALUK, THRISSUR DISTRICT BY ADVS. SRI .NIREESH MATHEW SRI.N.P.PRAJEESH RESPONDENT /COMPLAINANT-STATE: STATE OF KERALA, REPRESENTED BY THE PUBLIC PROSECUTOR,HIGH COURT OF KERALA ,ERNAKULAM,KOCHI 682 031. SRI C K PRASAD-PP THIS CRIMINAL MISC. CASE HAVING BEEN FINALLY HEARD ON 25.11.2019, THE COURT ON 06.01.2020 PASSED THE FOLLOWING: Eel Crl.MC.No.8945 OF 2018 (G) 2020/KER/288 2 R. NARAYANA PISHARADTI, J Cril.M.C No.8945 of 2018 ORDER The petitioner is the first accused in the case registered as C.R No. 14/2004 of the Kodungalloor Excise Range. 2. The offences alleged against the petitioner are punishable under Sections 55(a) and 58 of the Abkari Act, 1077. 3. The prosecution case is as follows: On 06.07.2004, the Excise Circle Inspector, Vadanappally conducted search of the house which was taken on rent by the first accused and seized 5206.500 litres of Indian Made Foreign Liquor of different brands from there. Investigation of the case revealed that it was the second accused who had brought the liquor to the aforesaid house and that the third accused had transported the liquor. 4. After completing the investigation of the case, chargesheet was filed against the three accused for the offences punishable under Sections 55(a) and 58 of the Abkari Act. The second and the third accused faced trial in the case S.C No. 204/2008 before the Additional Assistant Sessions Judge, Thirssur. As per Annexure-B judgment, the eee Crl.MC.No.8945 OF 2018 (G) 2020/KER/288 3 learned Additional Assistant Sessions Judge found the second and the third accused not guilty of the offences alleged against them and acquitted them. The petitioner, who is the first accused, was absconding and he had not faced trial and the case against him was split up and refiled as S.C No. 467/2015. 5. This petition is filed under Section 482 Cr.P.C for quashing the proceedings against the petitioner in the case S.C No. 467/2015 on the ground that the entire substratum of the prosecution case has been lost by virtue of Annexure-B judgment. 6. Heard the learned counsel for the petitioner and the learned Public Prosecutor. 7. Learned counsel for the petitioner contended that the second and the third accused who faced trial in S.C No. 204/2008 were acquitted not merely on the basis of insufficiency of evidence against them or the infirmities in the evidence adduced by the prosecution against them, but also on the ground that the officer who conducted the investigation of the case had no authority to do it. Learned counsel for the petitioner would contend that, even if the trial against the petitioner is conducted, the same situation will prevail and therefore, continuation of the prosecution of the petitioner would be a futile exercise. 8. Learned Public Prosecutor has submitted that the State has erie - Ble Sere Cr1.MC.No.8945 OF 2018 (G) 2020/KER/288 4 not filed any appeal against Annexure-B judgment. 9. Ona perusal of Annexure-B judgment, it is seen that one of the grounds for acquittal of the second and the third accused, who faced trial in that case, was the incompetency of the officer who conducted the investigation of the case. It is stated by the trial court in Annexure-B judgment as follows: The learned counsel for the accused argued that PW1 who was the circle inspector of excise, Vadanappally has no jurisdiction at all for registering this case and to conduct investigation as well as in filing the chargesheet. In the circumstances the learned counsel for the accused number 1 argued that the charge itself is not maintainable. In this case PW1 has no territorial jurisdiction within the jurisdiction of Kodungalloor range. There is a separate circle inspector of excise for the Kodungalloor range. The party of the circle inspector, Kodungalloor was with PW1, but that will not in any way help the prosecution to overcome this important aspect. The learned counsel for the accused was relying on the judgment of Honourable High Court in Rajan A.N v. State of Kerala (2014 (2) KLD 468) and also on the judgment in Hamsa Koya v. State of Kerala (2015 (2) KLT SN 25 (case number 35). In these decisions the Honourable High Court of Kerala made it clear that if the officer having no jurisdiction over the area conducted investigation and laid chargesheet then the cognizance taken by the court was against the mandate contained in Section 50 of Kerala Abkari Act. It was held that court had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offence erie - Bs ere Crl.MC.No.8945 OF 2018 (G) 2020/KER288 5 alleged in the complaint filed based on such investigation. Even the direction of Assistant Excise Commissioner will not confer any power on PW1 in conducting investigation and filing of chargesheet. Only by a notification of government it is possible to confer/powers on circle inspector of Vadanappally to act as Abkari Officer with respect to an offence committed within the jurisdiction of Kodungalloor range office. So on that ground itself this prosecution will fail. 10. It is now well settled that investigation of an offence under the Abkari Act can be done only by an Abkari Officer as defined under the Act. An officer who has no jurisdiction over the place where the occurrence took place has no authority to conduct the investigation of the case. Authority to conduct the investigation in such a case cannot also be delegated to such an officer by a superior officer (See Kunhanna Poojari v. State of Kerala: 2019(4) KHC (292)). 11. In the aforesaid circumstances, even if the prosecution against the petitioner is continued and trial against him is conducted, it would only be a futile exercise resulting in waste of judicial time. I am of the view that this is a case where the substratum of the prosecution case has been lost by virtue of Annexure-B judgment. Therefore, the proceedings against the petitioner are liable to be quashed by invoking the power of this Court under Section 482 Cr.P.C. 12. Consequently, the petition is allowed. The entire pes me - Bs ere Cr1.MC.No.8945 OF 2018 (G) 2020/KER/288 6 proceedings against the petitioner in the case S.C No. 467/2015, which are based on C.R No. 14/2004 of Kodungalloor Excise Range, are hereby quashed. Sd/-R.
